issue.title: DatasetHDD from DataFrame Pandas

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Problem**
I was working with the [Orchestrator module](https://alan-turing-institute.github.io/sktime/autogen/sktime.experiments.orchestrator.html) and I've noticed that the method `run()` needs list of datasets that has the `load()` method implemented. As you can see in the snippet below:

```    
def run(self, predict_on_runtime=True, save_strategies=True):
        """
        Method for running the orchestrator
        
        Parameters
        ----------
        predict_on_runtime : bool, optional (default=True)
            If True makes predictions after the estimator is trained
        save_strategies : bool, optional (default=True)
            If True saves the trained strategies on the disk
        """

        for task, data in zip(self._tasks, self._datasets):
            dts_loaded = data.load()
```
But on the documentation we assume that is a list of `DataFrame` pandas. Which doesn't have the `load()` method ([DataFrame documentation](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.html)). What is being used is a `DatasetHDD` list.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7353520/66721744-07be2280-eddc-11e9-95f8-71ee3d07736e.png)
Minor issue: typo on `skitme`->`sktime`.

**Solution**
**1. Easiest Solution**
Change the documentation. 
`datasets (pandas dataframe) – datasets in pandas skitme format` -> `datasets (list of DatasetHDD) – datasets in DatasetHDD format`

**2. Accept a DataFrame pandas as parameter to create a DatasetHDD**

**3. Create a method that converts DataFrame pandas to DatasetHDD**

**4. Create a .ts file from DataFrame pandas**
I haven't found this option on the code base. I mean, even if this exists, it should be easily to find on the documentation, we should have an update on the [loading data tutorial](https://alan-turing-institute.github.io/sktime/examples/loading_data.html) if that's the case. If we don't have a `create_tsfile_from_dataframe()`, this can solve the problem creating the tsfile and using it as parameter to the `DatasetHDD`. 

**5. DatasetRAM should be analogous to DatasetHDD**
The `load()` method on both classes are different. `DatasetHDD` splits the dataset, though the `DatasetRAM` doesn't. Maybe we could create a `Dataset` class and make that the parent class for both `DatasetRAM` and `DatasetHDD`.

What do you guys think? If I said something that is not right, please, let me know.

body: going through my issues ... don't we already have some of the features from the checkboxes above?
As far as I know nothing has been added since my last revision of the benchmarking code.
Some of the things are available in MLaut but I have not implemented them in sktime yet. I have been  focusing on my upgrade report, apologies for the delay.
oh, no problem - I just thought we should maybe tick the boxes that are already done, and once the upgrade is out of the way let's have a planning & architecture discussion

issue.title: integration with sktime
issue.body:
Integrate mlaut and sktime and ensure compatibility in the future

* Port [strategies and tasks from sktime](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/master/sktime/highlevel) into mlaut.
* Port current state of [benchmarking module from sktime](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/master/sktime/benchmarking) into mlaut.
* Future development of the ecosystem of packages (sktime, skpro, skpref, mlaut) could lead to all packages using the same base package. Ensure compatibility by separating the base classes.
* Translate all mlaut estimators to strategies by using the sktime strategy class.  
* Continue development by working through list in [issue #141 in sktime](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/141) 

Current state of this implementation is under development in the [imporved_workflow branch](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/mlaut/tree/improved_workflow) in the mlaut repo.

issue.title: Benchmarking issue141

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs

Initial PR dealing with issue #141.  


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* added additional unit tests for evaluator
* introduced functionality for calculating the runtime for fit and predict methods
* added some docstrings

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->


#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.

Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: hi @mloning can we close this issue, since there have been no comments since 2019?

Hm, this is partly implemented in the benchmarking module, but we may also want to revisit it. Perhaps also a good issue to raise with with @ngupta23, e.g., where what kind of general-purpose benchmarking functionality should sit - `pycaret` or `sktime`.

Design meeting, @ngupta23?

Just thinking out loud... I think this could be a generic framework in `sktime` where anyone could define a workflow in a function. This function should take X, y and other arguments needed to test at one point in time. Then the function could be passed to the back test framework in `sktime`

```python

## In sktime  ##
def back_test(workflow_func, backtest_cv, y, X=None, *kwargs):
    """
    benchmark using user's workflow
    """
    all_metrics = []
    all_cutoffs = []
    all_models = []
    for splits in backtest_cv(y):
        # Get X_train, y_train
        model = workflow_func(y_train, X_train, kwargs)
        
        # Get X_test, y_test
        y_pred = model.predict(X_test)
        metrics = get_metrics(y_pred, y_test)  # should support multiple metrics
        all_metrics.append(metrics)
        all_cutoffs.append(cutoff)
        all_models.append(model)  # could make this an optional return
    
    return all_metrics, all_cutoffs, all_models

def plot_back_test_results(all_metrics, all_cutoffs, y):
    """
    Plots the results of backtest
    """
    # plots results of back test -- similar to what @aiwalter has done in other places
```


```python       
## Users Custom Workflow ##
def pycaret_workflow(y, X, *setup_kwargs):
    """
    User defined workflow
    Returns a "finalized" model for the data
    """
    exp = pycaret.TimeSeriesExperiment()
    exp.setup(y, X, setup_kwargs)
    best = exp.compare_models()
    best_tuned = exp.tune_model(best)
    final_model = exp.finalize_model(best_tuned)
    return final_model    

## Evaluation
from sktime.backtest import back_test, plot_back_test_results  # or something like this
my_data = get_data("airline")
backtest_cv = ExpandingWindowSplitter(...)
all_metrics, all_cutoffs, all_models = back_test(
    workflow_func=pycaret_workflow, backtest_cv=backtest_cv, y=my_data, fold=3, fh=12
)
plot_back_test_results(all_metrics, all_cutoffs, my_data)

## go wild with the returned metrics and models :)
...
...
... 


```


cc: @Yard1 @pycaret, @tremamiguel
@TonyBagnall we could turn this into an enhancement proposal, that may be the better place for this. Any objections?
